page.title: 01The Downs Around Compton
page.content: The area covers part of the picturesque South Downs. It is aa farming area of gentle hills and slopes, parts of which are wooded and the land is used for crop rotation and grazing. There are two Downland villages. Compton lies between Compton Down and Telegraph Hill, has a village square with village stores - post office and 'pub' and nearby a church and 2 primary schools. A mile further north is a Boarding school for maladjusted children. Up Marden consists of only a few houses and a church. Of archealogical interest one can see some tumuli on Fernbeds Down and between these and Telegraph Hill a Long Barrow called 'Bevis's Thumb'. The local water supply comes from Apple Down where there is an underground reservoir.
